The Kolbe-Schmitt reaction is one of the industrially promising route for the production of hydroxybenzoic acids. In the present manuscript, alkali metal hydroxide free, direct carboxylation reaction has been demonstrated over heterogeneous CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. Different basic oxide (ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3) and corresponding Cu dispersed oxides (CuO/ZrO2, CuO/TiO2 and CuO/Bi2O3) were tested for direct carboxylation. The performance of catalysts were elucidated by comparing 4-HBA yield, phenol conversion, TON and TOF. Amongst the tested catalysts, ZrO2 showed highest catalytic activity with TON 0.1022 and TOF 0.0043, hence selected as an efficient catalyst support for Cu dispersion. The lowest value of E-factor (0.12) and PMI (0.39) was obtained for 5 wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. A series of Cu dispersed ZrO2 catalyst were synthesized via simple co-precipitation method with variable Cu precursor loading. Of the tested catalysts 1.25 wt% CuO loaded ZrO2 catalyst showed highest yield (62.57%) and phenol conversion (64.55%) under non-stringent operating condition (60 bar, 170 °C). The in-depth physicochemical characteristion were also conducted by using various analytical tools which dipicted the characterstic properties of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. The process intensification study was conducted to obtain optimum operating parameters for high yield and conversion. The catalyst recyclability performance study showed the consistency in 4-HBA yield and conversion for four consecutive recycle runs. The plausible reaction mechanism for production of 4-HBA over CuO/ZrO2 catalyst and catalytic cycle has also been proposed. Thus, the present process provides green and efficient route for alkali hydroxide free Kolbe- Schmitt reaction. The recent reports on climate change showed that in spite of a temporary breakdown in economic growth due to covid-19 lockdown, no such drastic reduction in CO2 emissions occurred [1]. The projected milestones set for reducing CO2 emission still stands nowhere close to reduction strategies thus, it remains a global objective today and may be for next decade. The utilisation of CO2, without obstructing urbanization has been proved as an effective way of dealing with the unprecedented increase in CO2 emission over CO2 capture and sequestration [2]. The conversion of CO2 into value added chemicals and fuels hits both the targets of CO2 reduction as well as production of green chemicals and fuels. Thermodynamically CO2 is highly stable molecule thus it is highly reluctant to most of organic reactions such as addition, elimination and reduction etc. But the thermodynamic barriers for CO2 stability can be taken over by integrating suitable catalysts [3]. However, several catalytic processes such as thermal catalysis, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and photoelectrochemical reactions have been used to covert CO2 into desirable value added product [4]. The catalytic reduction of CO2 has gained much attention in terms of its sustainability and economical feasibility to convert CO2 into commodity chemicals (formic acid, acetic acid, carbonates, polycarbonates etc.) and fuels (methanol, methane, dimethyl ether etc.) [5]. In addition to this, several industrially important benzoic acid derivatives were also produced by reacting CO2 and unsaturated compounds (alkynes, conjugated dienes, allenes and aromatic compounds etc.) together through carboxylation reactions [6]. The Kolbe-Schmitt reaction is an industrially important reaction for effective utilization of CO2 for production of aromatic hydroxy carboxylic acids. Kolbe-Schmitt reaction is well known since 1860s, which involve the electrophilic substitution of sodium salt of phenol on CO2 at about 80 atmospheric pressure [7]. This is one of the most widely used feasible and industrially applicable route for the production of aromatic hydroxy acids especially salicylic acid [8]. The dry sodium salt acts as the universal catalyst for selective production of salicylic acid. Although there are several factors such as type of alkaline metal salt, temperature and pressure which affects the selectivity of desire product [9]. However, major attention is given towards the production of salicylic acid as the major product. Beside salicylic acid, 4-HBA is also an industrially important aromatic hydroxy acid which can be obtained through carboxylation reaction by using phenol and CO2 [10]. The 4-HBA and its derivatives are of great advantages in the field of food industry both as preservatives and anti-oxidants [11]. It is also used as preservatives in pharmaceuticals and cosmetics industries [12]. Moreover, it is also utilised for the synthesis of liquid crystalline polyethers [13]. It can be synthesised by both chemical [14] and biological [15] methods. First ever synthesis of 4-HBA was reported by Gilman and Arntzen [16] by performing halogen metal interconversion reactions using halides based functional groups. Commercially 4-HBA is most widely synthesized through Kolbe-Schmitt reaction by heating potassium salt of phenol and CO2 pressure. The use potassium phenolate produce majorly 4-HBA with salicylic acid as minor product [17]. The major drawback of this method is (a) use of high CO2 pressure and (b) requirement of dry potassium phenolate. Thus, the maintaining anhydrous condition for potassium phenolate is very tedious unit operation and requires sophisticated reactor systems for handling which offer high capital and operating expenditures. Therefore, it became an utmost important task for upcoming researchers to develop an alternative simple methodology for production of 4-HBA. It was reported that reaction temperature and CO2 pressure plays an important role in determining the selectivity of ortho and para substituted product. The para carboxylation reaction of phenol was performed by using potassium ethyl carbonate under the 25 atm. CO2 pressure. When the reaction was carried out at 170 °C, salicylic acid (60.8%) was obtained as major product whereas, reaction above 200 °C formed 4-HBA as the major product with the yield of 93% [18]. Rahim et al. have explored alkali (Rb and Cs) and alkaline earth metals (Mg, Ca and Ba) phenoxide for carboxylation reaction and reported the effect of the chelation of intermediate and size of metal ions in determining the ratio of ortho and para substituted product [19]. Thereafter, Rahim et al. has also done the regioselective carboxylation of phenol by using tetraalkylammonium phenoxide and resulted into 56% yield of 4-HBA in presence of K2CO3 (125 °C 5.0 MPa CO2) [10]. K2CO3 was found to be an active catalyst for the carboxylation reaction of phenol. Iijima et al. have conducted carboxylation of phenol in presence of supercritical CO2 and obtained 68% salicylic acid and negligible 4-HBA as a by-product under optimised reaction condition (473 K, 8 MPa CO2, 10 h) [20]. Thus, till today hydroxides, alkali carbonate, and alkali and alkaline phenolate are only explored for the carboxylation of phenol. The use of heterogeneous catalysts has not been explored widely for production of 4-HBA by using Kolbe- Schmitt reaction. Till today only a single report exists in the literature for the direct carboxylation of phenol. Feliciano et al. used C@Fe-Al2O3 hybrid catalysts for the carboxylation of phenol under mild reaction conditions in aqueous medium [21]. The variation in temperature for catalyst preparation provides variable selectivity towards salicylic acid and 4-HBA, of the reported hybrid C@Fe-Al2O3 catalyst synthesised at 823 K showed selectivity for the formation of 4-HBA whereas C@Fe-Al2O3 at 923 K and 1023 K showed selectivity towards the formation of salicylic acid (>90%). Moreover, the formation of C6 compounds such as hydroquinone, benzoquinone, and catechol were also reported in both cases. However, it is an emergent need to develop the selective heterogeneous catalyst for high yield production of 4-HBA by using CO2. Thus, the present study aims to develop the selective catalyst for production of 4-HBA by utilising CO2 under non-stringent operating conditions. The cost- effective transition metal oxides catalyst was prepared by simple co-precipitation method and explored for direct carboxylation of phenol. The dispersion of Cu on ZrO2 showed the protagonistic effect for catalytic activity and showed selective formation of 4-HBA (Scheme 1 ). Thus, a series of catalyst with variable Cu loading were synthesized and tested for direct carboxylation reaction. The physiochemical and surface morphological characterization of synthesized catalyst was conducted by using various analytical methods such as ATR-FTIR (Attenuated Total Reflectance-Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy), XRD (X-ray Diffraction), BET (Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller), FEG-SEM (Field Emission Gun Scanning Electron Microscopy), EDX (Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy), XPS (X- ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) and ICP-OES (Induced Coupled Plasma optical emission Spectroscopy) analysis. In addition to this, the process intensification study was conducted to obtain the high yield of 4-HBA. The qualitative and quantitative analysis of the final product was conducted by using HPLC (High performance liquid chromatography). The characterization of isolated product was performed by using ATR-FTIR and 1H NMR (Nuclear magnetic resonance). Moreover, the plausible reaction for direct carboxylation of phenol to 4-HBA mechanism was elaborated with practical evidences. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zirconium oxychloride octahydrate (99.5%), and Copper nitrate trihydrate (98%) were obtained from Sigma Aldrich. Phenol crystals (99.5%), purchased from Thermo Fischer scientific. 25% ammonia solution procured from Sigma-Aldrich was used for precipitation. Deionized water (DI) was utilised for catalyst preparation. CO2 (100% purity) gas cylinders were purchased from local suppliers was used for reactions. All the chemicals were used as such without further purification. All the experiments were performed in triplicate and the final results were the mean of all three (± 3%). The standard curve of 4-HBA was obtained by plotting the calibration curve with R2 = 0.999. 2.2 Methods 2.2.1 The general process of direct carboxylation of phenol into 4-HBA The direct carboxylation reaction of phenol by using CO2 was conducted in the high-pressure batch autoclave reactor system (100 mL and MOC Hastelloy) well equipped with PID temperature and pressure indicator, four pitch bled impeller, sampling valve, inlet valve etc., The reactor was charged with 30 mL water, 1 g of phenol, 3 g catalyst under inert N2 atmosphere. After that, the reactor was purged with CO2 three times to remove pre-occupied gas and then pressurized with desired CO2 pressure (60 bar). The reactor vessel was heated with help of electric ban heater and constant temperature is monitored by using digital temperature indicator. The in-process analysis samples were collected by using sampling valve. After the completion of reaction, the reactor vessel was allowed to cool at room temperature by circulating cooling water in the cooling coil of reactor and then, reactor was depressurized into water scrubber. The catalyst from reaction mixture was separated by means of vacuum filtration. The recovered catalyst was washed with DI water (̴ 5 mL) and then dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C. The final liquid sample was collected and used for HPLC analysis by using Agilent 1200 series High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) system with a Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87H (300 mm x 7.8 mm) ion exclusion column coupled with UV- visible detector. The concentration of 4-HBA was calculated by using a standard formula. 2.2.2 Catalyst preparation Cu doped ZrO2 catalysts were prepeared by simple co-precipitation method by simulatanous precipitation of solution A and B. Solution A: 13 g of zirconium oxychloride was added in 20 mL water and properly mixed for 20 min. Solution B: 3.79 g of copper nitrate trihydrate in water. The solution B was slowly added into solution A under vigrous stirring and allowed to mix properly for atleast 30 min. The final solution was precipitated by dropwise addition of aqueous ammonia solution until the pH reached to 8–9. The resulting suspension was then stirred for 30 min and then heated to 80 °C for 6 h and thereafter agitated overnight for at 30 °C. The resulted precipitate was filtered by using vacuum filteration and washed with DI water until neutral pH . The filter cake was then dried in vacuum oven vacuum oven at 60 °C for 24 h, and then subjected to calcined at 700 °C for 4 h. 2.2.3 Catalyst characterization The ATR-FTIR analysis to investigate the active bonding and functional groups was conducted on Shimadzu IR Prestige-21 Kyoto Japan instrument, coupled with the Specac Golden Gate GS10500 ATR. The powder XRD was performed on Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer at room temperature with Cu (Kα) radiation having an accelerating voltage up to 40KV with scintillation counter detector and angle ranges from 10°−80° The surface morphological analysis of the synthesized catalysts were conducted by using FEG-SEM analysis on Carl Zeiss Supra 55 VP instrument coupled with Oxford Instruments X-MAX (20mm²) for EDX analysis. The specific surface area analysis of the catalysts was conducted by using N2 adsorption-desorption analysis on TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics, USA) instrument at liquid nitrogen temperature. The samples were initially degassed at 200 °C for 4 h. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm data, using BET (Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller) equation was used to calculate the surface area of the catalysts. The elemental composition of the catalyst was determined by ICP-OES analysis by using Agilent 5800 ICP-OES Instrument Dichroic Spectral Combiner (DSC) that enables synchronous radial and axial measurements. The XPS was performed using KRATOS Axis Supra XPS instrument equipped with a monochromatized Al Kα X-ray radiation source (normally 75 W). Binding energies were calibrated based on the graphite C peak at 284.6 V. 2.2.4 Quantitative and qualitative analysis of 4-HBA HPLC analysis All the samples were tested for calculating the yield of 4-HBA and conversion of phenol by using Agilent 1200 series HPLC system with a Bio-Rad Aminex HPX-87H (300 mm x 7.8 mm) ion exclusion column coupled with UV detector. ATR- FTIR analysis The precipitate of 4-HBA from reaction mixture was obtained as described in the supporting information. All the characteristics peaks of the chemical bond and associated functional groups were observed in the spectra. The important absorption bands of 4-HBA at peaks are OH group attached to phenol (3400–3000 cm−1), OH of carboxylic acid (3000- 2500 cm−1, 840 cm−1), and C=O of carboxylic acid (1668 cm−1) [23]. All these bonds has provided the preliminary conformation of presence of 4-HBA as the product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst performance evaluation test The metal oxides are widely explored as a catalyst for their characteristic acidity and basicity for CO2 reduction reactions [24]. In our previous study it was observed that the dispersion of copper on TiO2 has played a crucial role for CO2 activation [25]. The basic oxides such as MgO, CsO, ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3 has been explored as an efficient catalyst for CO2 reduction, hydrogenation, esterification, transesterification, CO2 activation and adsorption etc. [26–29]. Thus, in present study ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3 were selected as catalyst for direct Carboxylation of phenol to 4-HBA. The performance of catalysts were evaluated by comparing the yield of 4-HBA, TON (turnover number), TOF (turnover frequency), Process mass intensity (PMI) and E-Factor. 3.1.1 Catalyst screening for direct carboxylation of phenol to p-HBA Basic metal oxides ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3 were synthesized via simple precipitation method followed by calcination using ZrOCl2·8H2O, Ti(i-OPr)4, and Bi(NO3)2·5H2O, respectively. The performance of all the selected catalyst for conversion of phenol into 4-HBA is shown in (Table 1 ). The blank reaction was conducted in absence of catalyst and it was noted that there was no formation of 4-HBA. While the addition of catalyst shows remarkable effect towards selective formation of 4-HBA. It was noted that all the selected metal oxides catalyst ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3 showed the formation of 4-HBA with 7% - 4% yield. Of the tested single metal oxides, ZrO2 showed highest yield of 4-HBA. As ZrO2 has been reported as an active catalyst support due to its dual acidic-basic and redox surface properties with excellent thermal stability [30,31]. Moreover, the characteristic basicity and surface area promotes the effective CO2 adsorption. Thus, the higher yield of 4-HBA (7%) was observed in presence of ZrO2. It has been found that the performance of binary metal oxides was superior over single metal oxide for conversion of CO2 into various chemicals [32]. The dispersion of transition metal such as Cu, Ni, and Zn etc., provides efficient activity to binary metal oxide catalyst [33–35]. More specifically, Cu dispersed binary metal oxides has proven their activity for CO2 activation and polarization of C=O in order to develop the electrophilic centre on C-atom of CO2 [36,37]. Thus, in the present study transition metal Cu was selected for dispersion with metal oxide support. However, 5 wt% copper precursor loaded ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3 catalysts were synthesized by simple co-precipitation method followed by calcination and tested for direct carboxylation of phenol. The performance of Cu dispersed catalyst for direct carboxylation of phenol is shown in (Table 1). The comparative study of bare metal oxide and Cu-dispersed metal oxide catalyst showed the higher yield of 4-HBA, TON and TOF. The yield of 4-HBA, TON and TOF is significantly increased after dispersion of Cu with corresponding metal oxide. The maximum yield of 4-HBA, TON and TOF was observed for 5 wt% CuO/ZrO2 and 5wt% Cu/Bi2O3 catalyst. While the highest yield of 4-HBA (11%) with TON 0.166 and TOF 0.0067 was observed for 5 wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. Thus, the Cu-ZrO2 interface bonding plays a crucial role in the selective formation of 4-HBA as the product and minimised the formation of by-products [38,39]. Hence, the Cu dispersed ZrO2 catalyst was selected for further catalyst screening study. 3.1.2 E-Factor and PMI calculation The performance evaluation of catalyst in term of E-factor and PMI is an important parameter to establish environment friendly sustainable process [40]. The E-factor provides the calculation of amount of waste generated per unit mass of the product while the PMI evaluates the green aspects of chemical reactions based on the mass metrics of the steps involved during process development [41]. Thus, in order to evaluate the environmental performance of catalytic process for manufacturing of bulk chemicals, calculation of E-Factor and PIM plays a crucial role to meet the environmental friendly targets of process. In the present study, screening of catalysts (ZrO2, TiO2, Bi2O3, 5 wt% CuO/ZrO2, 5 wt% CuO@TiO2 and 5 wt% CuO@Bi2O3) for direct carboxylation were evaluated by comparing both the E-Factor and PMI. The E-Factor and PMI of selected catalysts is shown in (Fig 1 ). E − F a c t o r = ( m a s s o f w a s t e m a s s o f 4 − H B A ) and , PMI = ( Mass of raw materials used ( Kg ) m a s s o f 4 − H B A ( K g ) ) It was observed that all the tested catalysts shows the E-Factor < 0.67. According to the Roger Sheldon scale, the E-factor in the range of < 1- 5 is suitable for manufacturing process of bulk chemicals [42]. Thus, according to Roger Sheldon scale all the tested catalyst are suitable for green and environment friendly synthesis of 4-HBA. In general it was noted that the E-factor and PMI of all the bare metal oxides (ZrO2, TiO2, and Bi2O3) are higher than the corresponding Cu-dispersed form (5wt% CuO/ZrO2, 5wt% CuO@TiO2 and 5wt% CuO@Bi2O3). Thus, it can be speculated that the dispersion of Cu into the metal oxide has reduced the E-factor and PMI. The lowest value of E-factor (0.12) was obtained for 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with PMI (0.39). Moreover, the highest yield (11.35%), conversion (16.12%) and TON (0.16) was obtained for 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. Thus, the 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was shortlisted for the further study of copper precursor loading. 3.2 Copper precursor loading It was observed that the dispersion of Cu in the metal oxide has remarkably increased the activity of Cu-dispersed catalysts as compared to its corresponding bare metal oxide. Thus, the presence of dispersed Cu on the metal oxide architecture imparts the active sites on the surface catalysts. However, the concentration of Cu in the catalyst play an important role to determine the catalytic activity of the desired product. Moreover, the specific ability of ZrO2 to accommodate Cu in its lattice structure upto a certain limit was reported [43,44]. Thus, the shortlisted 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with best performances was selected for study the influence of CuO loading. The various catalyst with variable amount of CuO loading over the ZrO2 support were synthesized by changing the amount of Cu-precursor from 0.6 to 10 wt% w.r.t. ZrO2. The influence of Cu precursor concentration on 4-HBA yield, phenol conversion, TON and PMI is shown in (Fig. 2 ). The performance of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with variable Cu-loading was evaluated by comparing the yield, conversion, TON and PMI for respective catalyst with corresponding Cu-loading. It was reported that the metal oxide backbone architecture have characteristic ability to hold and occupy the transition metal upto certain concentration [45]. While, the presence of active metal at higher concentration increases the extent of active sites on catalyst surface resulting increased catalytic performance [46,47]. However, the optimum ability to hold the respective transition metal restricts the loading beyond the specific limit. Of the six variables with different Cu-precursor loading from 0.6 to 10 wt% w.r.t. ZrO2, it was observed that 1.25 wt% Cu loaded catalyst (1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2) provided the maximum yield of 4-HBA (16.43%) with maximum TON (0.12) and minimum PMI (0.26) value. While it was noted that the yield of 4-HBA decrease on increasing and decreasing Cu-precursor loading beyond 1.25 wt% hence accordingly PMI followed the increasing trend. The remarkable drop in the TON was observed with increased Cu-precursor loading. Thus, it clearly depicted the increased number of active sites with respect to increasing Cu-precursor loading but the yield of 4-HBA decreasing simultaneously. The drop in yield of 4-HBA depicted the overloading of Cu-precursor beyond certain limit, as higher loading leads to the poor dispersion of Cu over the ZrO2 support due to the formation of particle aggregates which decreases the selectivity of desire product [48]. Thus, 1.25 wt% Cu precursor loaded catalyst (1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2) was chosen for further process intensification study to obtain the maximum yield and conversion. 3.3 Catalyst characterization In the catalyst performance evaluation test it was observed that 1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2 is an excellent choice to obtain the maximum yield of 4-HBA with minimum TON and desirable PMI and E-Factor. Thus, 1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was selected for in-detailed characterization of chemical and surface morphological features using various analytical tools. 3.3.1 ATR- FTIR Spectroscopy analysis The presence of metal oxide bonds and other functional groups of the bare ZrO2 and 1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2 was confirmed by using ATR- FTIR analysis. The ATR- FTIR analysis was conducted on Shimadzu IR Prestige-21 Kyoto Japan instrument, coupled with Specac Golden Gate GS10500 ATR assembly. The overlay of ATR- FTIR spectra of both bare ZrO2 and 1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2 was done as shown (Fig. 3 ). The characteristic absorption bands with medium and strong transmission in ATR-FTIR was observed in both bare ZrO2 and 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. The major absorption bands both bare ZrO2 and 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst were observed in finger print region specifically 500–1500 cm−1 and fundamental region specifically 3000–3500 cm−1. The characteristic peaks at 3398 cm−1, and 1629 cm−1 in ATR-FTIR spectra of both bare ZrO2 and 5wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst were attributed to the stretching vibration of –OH groups present on the surface of ZrO2 [49] while, peak at 927 cm−1 and 514 cm−1 are attributed to monoclinic and tetragonal phase of ZrO2 [50] while peak at 1355 cm−1 is attributed to -O-H bond [51]. The presence of characteristics peaks of ZrO2 ATR-FTIR spectra of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst indicates the proper dispersion of Cu into the ZrO2 lattice [52]. The further confirmation of presence of CuO in ZrO2 lattices structure was studied by using XRD and SEM analysis. 3.3.2 XRD analysis The XRD analysis of CuO@ ZrO2 catalyst was performed to examine the diffraction pattern of the planes. The XRD pattern of CuO@ ZrO2 catalyst was obtained on Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer instrument with Cu Kα (1.54 Å) radiation, and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst sample were scanned from 0.0 to 80° The XRD spectra of CuO/ZrO2 is as shown (Fig. 4 ). The XRD pattern of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst clearly depicted the crystalline surface texture. XRD pattern depicted several characteristic sharp peaks at corresponding 2 theta value. The characteristics planes of both the monoclinic (m) and tetragonal (t) phase of ZrO2 were found at 2θ value of 28.05°, 31.33°, 33.98°, 34.25°, 35.15°, 35.71°, 49.02°, 49.89°, 50.31°, 59.89°, 60.10°, 61.40°, 74.74° and 75.24° (JCPDS 37–1484) and 2θ value of 30.4°, 35.5°, 50.5°, 73.05°, 74.58° according to JCPDS 80–0784, respectively [53,54]. Thus, the mixed phases of ZrO2 are present in the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. In addition to this, all the characteristics peaks of Cu at 2θ 35.59°, 41.09°, 49.53°, and 65.85° were also noted in the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst, which provides the confirmation for the dispersion of Cu onto monoclinic and tetragonal backbone of ZrO2 [55]. Thus, it can be speculated that the specific selectivity to the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was achieved due to the existence of CuO in the mixed phases of ZrO2 [56] . 3.3.3 FEG-SEM & EDX analysis The surface morphology of heterogeneous catalyst plays an important role in the selectivity of desired reaction products. Priscilla et al. have reported the effect of morphology of ZrO2 for hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over Pd/ZrO2 catalyst [57]. Thus, in order to study the surface features of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst, FEG- SEM images of both bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst were captured at different magnification to check the morphological difference between bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 (Fig.S2 and Fig.S3). The FEG-SEM images of bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst at different magnification scale are shown (Fig. 5 ). The FEG-SEM images of both bare ZrO2 and Cu@ZrO2 catalyst clearly depicted the agglomerated partials with difference in surface morphological features. It can be observed that bare ZrO2 consists of agglomerates of quasi spherical and elongated shape particles, while in case of Cu@ZrO2 catalyst the morphology remains consistent but the size of agglomerated particles is reduced. The morphology of the CuO/ZrO2 was found in good agreement with the reported study [58,59]. In addition to this, EDX analysis was conducted to obtain the elemental composition of the transition metals present in the catalyst. The EDX and elemental mapping of bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was shown in (Fig. S3 and S4). The EDX spectra of bare ZrO2 depicted the peaks at Kα 15.74 eV, 8.0 eV for the presence of Zr and O, respectively into the bare CuO/ZrO2. The presence of peak at Kα 15.74 eV, 8.0 eV, and 0.52 eV in EDX spectra of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst depicted the presence Cu, Zr and O, respectively into the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst architecture. Thus, the presence of Cu in EDX spectra of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst confirms the dispersion of Cu on catalyst surface. The observation of EDX analysis are in the good agreement with the XRD and ATR-FTIR analysis. Moreover, the weight percentage of Cu, Zr and O elements obtained from EDX analysis (Fig. S3) also provides the confirmation for the amount of Cu loaded on ZrO2. In addition to this, ICP-OES analysis of CuO/ZrO2 catlyst was conduted to estimate the exact amount of Cu loading on Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. The ICP- OES analysis provides further confirmation for stoichemoetric loading of Cu on CuO/ZrO2 catalyst (Table S1). The EDX and ICP-OES results were found in good correlation with each other. 3.3.4 Specific surface area (SBET) analysis The surface area of the catalyst is also a crucial factor on which the activity of catalyst depends [60]. The surface area of both bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was analysed by performing BET analysis. The BET surface area of the bare ZrO2 and Cu@ZrO2 catalyst was calculated from N2 adsorption- desorption isotherm. The BET surface are analysis was conducted on TriStar II 3020 (Micromeritics, USA) instrument. The N2 adsorption- desorption isotherm of bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 are shown in Fig. 6 (A). The N2 adsorption- desorption isotherm plot of both bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst depicted the type-IV isotherm with surface area 241.98 m2/g and 76.82 m2/g, respectively. The presence of type-IV isotherm with hysteresis loop at relative pressure P/Po 0.6 to 0.91 in the N2 adsorption- desorption isotherm plot of both bare ZrO2 and CuO/ZrO2 catalyst attributed to the mesoporous surface structure. However, the remarkable drop in the surface area of ZrO2 was observed after Cu dispersion, this might be attributed to the occupancy of active surface area and porous structure of ZrO2 matrix by CuO [25]. Furthermore, the BJH-pore size distribution plot of the CuO/ZrO2 was conducted to examine the nature of pore distribution of the particles over the catalytic surface. The pore size distribution spectra obtained by BJH method as shown in (Fig. 6(B)). The BJH-pore size distribution plot depicted the non-uniform porous structure of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with a multimodal porous system of the particles range from 1.5 – 12 nm. It was observed that the pore volume was decreased in CuO/ZrO2 as compared to bare ZrO2. The drop in pore volume could be attributed to the occupied Cu into the porous matrix of ZrO2. The observation is in agreement with the reported study for the suitability of bigger lattice structure of ZrO2 to accommodate Cu. 3.3.5 XPS analysis The XPS analysis of CuO/ZrO2 was performed to elucidate the chemical and electronic states of the associated elements. Fig. 7 (A) shows the wide survey scan of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst performed by varying the binding energy ranges from 0- 1200 eV. It was observed that the XPS spectra of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst showed characteristics peaks of the Cu, Zr, and O elements only and no other elements were found in the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. The high resolution spectra of Zr was performed with the binding energy ranges from 177- 190 eV. The Zr 3d Gaussian fitted spectra was found to be deconvoluted into two peaks as shown in Fig. 7(B). The peak at binding energies of 181.74 and 184.18 eV was attributed to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 states of Zr respectively [61]. This has confirmed that Zr exits in Zr4+ state in the catalyst [62,63]. The high resolution spectra of Cu 2p is shown in Fig. 7(C), which is divided into four peaks, two main peaks and two satellite peaks. The peaks at 931.8 eV and 951.6 eV are assigned to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 respectively [64]. In addition to these, presence of satellite peak (S1) near to 941.5 and (S2) at 961.4 eV, implies that Cu exists in Cu2+ state in the ZrO2 host [64,65]. Fig. 7(D) shows the resolution spectra of O 1 s which has only peak at 530.6 eV which is attributed to the surface –OH groups present on the catalytic surface [66]. Thus, the comprehensive study of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst through XPS, XRD and SEM analysis provides the presence of CuO on the surface of ZrO2. 4 Process intensification studies The catalyst performance evaluation test and in-detail catalyst characterization showed the excellent performance of 1.25 wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with characteristics surface morphological properties. Thus, in order to improve the yield and selectivity of the desired product at optimum operating conditions further process intensification study was conducted to check the influence of operating parameters. The reaction operating parameters such as catalyst concentration, temperature, time, CO2 pressure, and phenol concentration etc., were studied as below. 4.1 Influence of catalyst concentration The optimum catalyst concentration is an important parameter to meet the desired product selectivity and yield. Particularly, in heterogeneous catalysis the amount of catalyst used in the reaction decides the concentration of available active sites [67]. The carboxylation reaction of aromatics are highly sensitive towards the catalyst concentration, the presence of active sites in excess decreases the selectivity of desire product by forming oxidative side products [68]. Thus, in addition to optimum loading of transition metal, desirable catalyst concentration is crucial parameter to obtain maximum yield and selectivity. In order to study the effect of catalyst concentration was determined based on the presence of catalyst in the reaction mixture. The influence of catalyst concentration on 4-HBA yield and phenol conversion is shown (Fig. 8 ). It was noted that on increasing catalyst concentration from 0.008 to 0.067 g/mL there was no remarkable change in conversion observed, with increase in catalyst concentration. However, notable effect of catalyst concentration was observed on% yield of 4-HBA, the yield of 4-HBA increases gradually (10% to 32%) up to 0.050 catalyst loading and the decreases slightly beyond 3 wt% loading phenol. The higher concentration of heterogeneous catalyst increases the solid concentration in the reaction which could affect the mass transfer resistance, blocking of active sites and agglomeration etc. [69]. Thus, in spite of gradual rise in the yield the 0.050 catalyst loading was selected. As there is no remarkable improvement in 4-HBA yield beyond 0.050 catalyst loading. The maximum conversion of phenol (35%) and yield of 4-HBA (32%) was obtained at 0.050 catalyst loading thus, it is selected for further process intensification study. 4.2 Influence of reaction time The reaction time is another important parameter for obtaining the higher selectivity and of desired product with the higher productivity [67]. The optimum contact time of reactive substrates and intermediates provides the higher yield of targeted product. In order to design industrially viable process, process productivity is a crucial parameter which can be enhanced by tuning reaction time [70]. The shorter reaction time will also contribute to drop the capital investment by decreasing the volume requirement of unit operations [71]. Thus, in order to design industrially scalable process reaction time plays crucial role. The direct carboxylation of phenol over CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was studied for influence of reaction time. The influence of reaction time on 4-HBA yield and conversion is shown (Fig. 9 ). The continuous in-process analysis with respective to the reaction was conducted to check the phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield. It was observed that upto 2 h there was no formation of 4-HBA but after 2.5 hr formation of 4-HBA was noted on HPCL chromatogram. (Fig.S9) Thus, to study the influence of reaction time direct carboxylation reactions were conducted beyond 4 h reaction time (4 h to 28 h). It was noted that reaction time significantly affected the phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield, on increasing reaction time both conversion and yield increases drastically upto 12 h. However, beyond 12 h, was almost negligible increment in the yield and conversion was noted. The slower increment in reaction time < 4 h and > 12 h reaction time depicted the attainment of saturation of active sites due to CO2 and reactive intermediates, respectively. No formation of 4-HBA< 4 h clearly depicted the requirement of optimum time for adsorption and polarization CO2 on catalyst surface, the study of adsorption behaviour of CO2 on catalyst provides strong evidence for this observation (Fig.S7). It was noted that CO2 adsorption increases with contact time, thus surface adsorption of CO2 followed by polarization are the rate limiting steps for direct carboxylation of phenol [72]. The presence of both acidic and basic active sites on ZrO2 [73] and Cu metal is reported for the effective CO2 adsorption and polarization [74,75]. The maximum phenol conversion (35%) and 4-HBA yield (32%) was obtained at 12 h. Thus, the reaction time of 12 h was selected for further study. 4.3 Influence of reaction temperature The conventional Kolbe-Schmitt reaction offers the > 125 °C reaction temperature in presence of 100 bar CO2 pressure. Selectivity of Kolb- Schmitt reaction towards ortho and para substituted benzoic acid with reaction temperature was reported [18]. Dunn et al. have reported the formation of decarboxylation products 220 °C [76]. Thus, the reaction temperature plays crucial role to obtain the selective benzoic acid. Moreover, the reaction kinetics of carboxylation reaction is also influenced reaction temperature [77]. Thus, in present study influence of reaction temperature was studied by conduction direct carboxylation reaction by varying the reaction temperature ranges from 130 °C to 200 °C. The influence of reaction temperature on phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield is shown (Fig. 10 ). It was observed that the on increasing reaction temperature yield and conversion increases drastically upto 170 °C, then increases gradually. Beyond 170 °C there is no remarkable effect of reaction temperature on phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield. The maximum phenol conversion (47%) and 4-HBA yield (45%) was obtained at 170 °C reaction temperature, thus it is selected for further study. 4.4 Influence of CO2 pressure The direct carboxylation of phenol appoints CO2 as one of the key raw material hence the pressure of CO2 is an important parameter of study for further enhancement of conversion and yield. Thus, the influence of CO2 pressure was studied by changing the CO2 pressure in the reactor from 20 bar to 60 bar. The influence of CO2 pressure on phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield is as shown (Fig. 11 ). The CO2 pressure remarkably affected the phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield. Of the tested range of CO2 pressure, it was noted that yield and conversion increases drastically upto 50 bar. However, on further increase in CO2 pressure beyond 50 bar there was no remarkable increment in the yield and conversion. This could be attributed to attainment of surface saturation thus further increment does not resulted into improvement in yield. The high pressure of CO2 at surface is responsible for the retardation of substrate catalyst interaction [78,79]. Moreover, the stoichiometric concentration of both CO2 and phenol are required for the for direct carboxylation reaction. Thus, the 50 bar CO2 pressure with maximum phenol conversion (60%) and 4-HBA yield (57%) was selected for further study. 4.5 Influence of phenol concentration The substrate concentration is an important parameter to develop the industrially feasible process. Higher substrate concentration promotes the process productivity, thus it contributes in reducing both capital and operating expenditures. In the present study to check the influence of substrate concentration phenol concentration was varied from 0.4 to 13%. Influence of phenol concentration on conversion and yield is shown Fig. 12 . It was noted that the substrate concertation remarkably contributed to improve the phenol conversion and 4-HBA yield. The lower phenol concentration resulted into low conversion and yield while higher concentration favoured to high yield. Of the tested range of phenol concentration, maximum yield (65%) and conversion (70%) was obtained at 6.68% phenol loading. On further increment in phenol loading beyond 6.68%,% yield decreased gradually. It was reported that at higher concentration of substrate, the carboxylation reaction is rate limited [80]. However, at 3.34% phenol concentration the conversion is 64% while 4-HBA yield is 62% which depicted the higher selectivity as compared to 6.68% phenol loading. Thus, 3.34% phenol concentration was selected for further study. 4.6 Reusability study of the catalyst The heterogeneous catalyst are mostly preferred over the homogeneous catalyst because of their ease of separation and recyclability [81]. Thus, the recyclability and reusability of heterogeneous catalyst is important for the development of scalable catalytic process. In the present study, the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst was tested for four consecutive runs to evaluate its recyclability and reusability. Influence of catalyst recyclability on 4-HBA yield and phenol conversion is shown (Fig. 13 ). The catalyst was separated through vacuum filtration and washed with sufficient amount of water and dried in vacuum oven at 60 °C then used for next recycle run. The recyclability study for four consecutive runs depicted the consistency in yield and conversion. There was no remarkable drop in the performance of catalyst during recycle. The physicochemical characterisation of recycled catalyst was conducted by using ATR- FTIR (Fig. S4), FEG- SEM (Fig. S5) and EDX (Fig. S6) to confirm the chemical and surface morphological change during recycle. It was observed that there is no chemical and morphological change during catalyst recycle. In addition to this the weight percent of elements of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst obtained by EDX analysis was found to be same as that of fresh catalyst which means that no leaching of metals was found after reaction. Therefore, it can be concluded that the synthesised CuO/ZrO2 is stable and robust under the optimized operating conditions. 4.7 Plausible reaction mechanism over CuO/ZrO2 catalyst surface The synthesized catalyst showed the characteristic physicochemical properties such as, (a) mesoporous structure (b) uniform dispersion of CuO on ZrO2 (c) existence of tetragonal and monoclinic phases of ZrO2 (d) existence of Cu+2 and Zr+4 and (e) –Zr-O-Cu- or –Zr-O-Cu-Zr-O- backbone architecture. Thus, the direct carboxylation of phenol proceed through different steps such as (i) CO2 adsorption and activation (ii) phenoxide ion formation (iii) nucleophilic addition and, (iv) proton transfer step. The plausible reaction mechanism of the formation of 4-HBA product over CuO/ZrO2 catalyst is shown in Fig. 14 . The CuO/ZrO2 catalyst has both the acidic and basic sites over the surface due to presence of metal centres (Zr4+and Cu2+) and surface oxygen (O2 −). The reaction was initiated by the adsorption of CO2 due to characteristic porosity and affinity of ZrO2 backbone which further activated through polarization due to presence of Cu2+ in ZrO2 backbone [82]. The polarization of CO2 has favoured the formation of electrophilic centre on C atom of CO2. The presence of Lewis acid sites (Zr+4) promoted the proton transfer which led the formation of phenoxide ion that undergoes further resonance stabilization at para-position [83]. The nucleophilic addition of p-phenoxide ion resulted into carboxylate intermediate which on proton transfer resulted into 4-HBA. [83,84] Thus, in an overall catalytic cycle there is an involvement of (a) adsorption (b) surface reaction (d) desorption and (e) catalyst regeneration step. The plausible catalytic cycle for direct carboxylation over CuO/ZrO2 catalyst is shown Fig. 15 . The Lewis acid sites Zr+4 and Cu+2 leads to formation of bidentate CO2 in the adsorption step. The mode of adsorption of CO2 over the catalyst surface has been predicted by performing the ATR-FTIR study using KM equation as shown in Fig. S7. It can be seen that two significant peaks at 1331 cm−1 and 1571 cm−1 were found which signifies the bidentate chelating mode of CO2 adsorption over the CuO/ZrO2 catalyst [85]. The polarization of CO2 is favourable to surface reaction in between polarized CO2 and phenoxide ion which form carboxylate ion which on further isomerization through proton transfer produces 4-HBA. The resulting 4-HBA desorbed from the catalyst surface resulting in availability of fresh active site for CO2. Accordingly, this cyclic process continued throughout catalytic cycle. 5 Conclusion The reported study demonstrates CuO/ZrO2 catalysed Kolbe-Schmitt reaction for the direct carboxylation of phenol selectively into 4-HBA. To the best of our knowledge this is the first report for an alkali metal hydroxide free Kolbe-Schmitt reaction. The synthesis of mixed phase of ZrO2 through co-precipitation followed by Cu dispersion resulted in CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with characteristic physicochemical properties. The presence of selective metal oxide (ZrO2) in combination with optimized concentration of metal precursor plays crucial role to obtain maximum 4-HBA yield. The 5wt% Cu precursor loaded catalyst showed the excellent performance to obtain highest TON (0.16) with TOF (0.0067). Similarly, elucidation of E-factor and PMI for 5wt% showed the environmental feasibility of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. The in-depth catalyst characterization depicted the presence of (a) mesoporous catalyst surface (1.5- 12 nm) (b) uniform dispersion of CuO (Cu2+) over ZrO2 (Zr4+) and (c) presence of tetragonal and monoclinic ZrO2. The process intensification study showed the remarkable effect of operating parameters such as catalyst concentration, CO2 pressure, reaction time and temperature etc. The optimized reaction parameters showed 62.57% yield of 4-HBA with 64.55% phenol conversion. The recyclability study of the catalyst showed catalyst robustness for multiple recycle runs without any loss in its activity. Comprehensively, the reported protocol has demonstrated an alkali metal hydroxide free approach for Kolbe-Schmitt reaction to produce 4-HBA selectively. Thus, the dual goal of CO2 utilization and green approach for production of hydroxy benzoic acid are achieved together. Since, the present study provides an efficient, sustainable and economical route for Kolbe-Schmitt reaction by introducing stable, robust, recyclable CuO/ZrO2 catalyst with high yield of 4-HBA. coredata.dc:description: The Kolbe-Schmitt reaction is one of the industrially promising route for the production of hydroxybenzoic acids. In the present manuscript, alkali metal hydroxide free, direct carboxylation reaction has been demonstrated over heterogeneous CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. Different basic oxide (ZrO2, TiO2 and Bi2O3) and corresponding Cu dispersed oxides (CuO/ZrO2, CuO/TiO2 and CuO/Bi2O3) were tested for direct carboxylation. The performance of catalysts were elucidated by comparing 4-HBA yield, phenol conversion, TON and TOF. Amongst the tested catalysts, ZrO2 showed highest catalytic activity with TON 0.1022 and TOF 0.0043, hence selected as an efficient catalyst support for Cu dispersion. The lowest value of E-factor (0.12) and PMI (0.39) was obtained for 5 wt% CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. A series of Cu dispersed ZrO2 catalyst were synthesized via simple co-precipitation method with variable Cu precursor loading. Of the tested catalysts 1.25 wt% CuO loaded ZrO2 catalyst showed highest yield (62.57%) and phenol conversion (64.55%) under non-stringent operating condition (60 bar, 170 °C). The in-depth physicochemical characteristion were also conducted by using various analytical tools which dipicted the characterstic properties of CuO/ZrO2 catalyst. The process intensification study was conducted to obtain optimum operating parameters for high yield and conversion. The catalyst recyclability performance study showed the consistency in 4-HBA yield and conversion for four consecutive recycle runs. The plausible reaction mechanism for production of 4-HBA over CuO/ZrO2 catalyst and catalytic cycle has also been proposed. Thus, the present process provides green and efficient route for alkali hydroxide free Kolbe- Schmitt reaction.
